Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 53343-001  
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance Cluster (C-KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
Mainstreaming Impact Evaluation Methodologies, 
Approaches, and Capacities in Selected Developing 
Member Countries
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CTA  –  technical assistance cluster 
  DMC  –  developing member countries 
  ERCD  –  Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
  IE  –  impact evaluation 
  IEC  –  impact evaluation committee 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster aims to mainstream impact 
evaluation1 (IE) to improve the development effectiveness of project and policy interventions in 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs). The TA will (i) support IE 
studies of ADB-financed sovereign interventions or pilot interventions under consideration for 
finance, and (ii) increase the awareness and capacity of DMCs to carry out IE and use IE results. 
 
2.  The TA is included in the ADB Management approved 2019 results-based workplan of 
ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD).2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  ADB commits more than $30 billion each year to investments (inclusive of cofinancing), 
but empirical evidence regarding the attributable impacts of the financed interventions remains 
limited. Following project completion, self-evaluations are conducted to rate performance and are 
subject to validation by  ADB’s Independent Evaluation Department. In selected cases, the 
Independent  Evaluation  Department  conducts  project  performance  evaluations,  and  rating 
patterns are synthesized in various evaluation studies. However, these analyses typically do not 
provide empirical estimates of the effects of project interventions on outcomes of interest, and 
understanding of these effects often remains rooted in assumptions that have not been empirically 
tested. 
  
4.  This has remained so, even as the development profession has increasingly recognized 
the need for rigorous IE methodologies (including randomized experiments and appropriate 
econometric approaches) to isolate the effects of interventions from those of confounding factors.3 
The number of rigorous IEs published annually has risen from tens of studies around year 2000 
to over 500 by 2015.4 During this period, the conduct of IEs to test development interventions has 
become a central focus of the world’s top research economists, including those awarded the 2019 
Nobel Prize in economics.5 The conduct of IEs has greatly expanded in other international 
financial institutions, where hundreds are now ongoing. Fast-paced private industries, such as 
information technology, medicine, and marketing, have also rapidly escalated the use of IE 
methods to test consumer responses to innovations before they are scaled widely. Beyond 
offering findings to inform improvements, the process of IE has also been found to improve project 
implementation by clarifying key assumptions, so that projects have fewer delays and faster 
disbursement.6 
 
5.  In parallel, recent developments in data collection technologies and analysis tools present 
opportunities to undertake IEs that are nimble and can more rapidly respond to operational needs. 
Very large data sets (“big data”) are increasingly collected and available through automated 
 
1  Impact evaluation refers to empirical estimates of the effects of interventions and their statistical significance. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 October 2019. 
3  Examples of recent innovations include development of the “synthetic controls” method; refinements to propensity 
score approaches, such as machine learning-based propensity score estimation; and double robust regression, 
marginal treatment effects models, and improved correlated random coefficients models. 
4  H. White and D.A. Raitzer. 2017. Impact Evaluation of Development Interventions: A Practical Guide. Manila. Figure 
1.2 of this book describes where impact evaluation fits in the project cycle of development organizations, including 
ADB. 
5  Esther Duflo, Abhijit Banerjee, and Michael Kremer received the 2019 Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences 
in Memory of Alfred Nobel for rigorous randomized impact evaluations in development economics. 
6  A. Legovini, V. Di Maro, and C. Piza. 2015. Impact evaluation helps deliver development projects. Policy Research 
Working Paper No. WPS 7157; Impact Evaluation series. Washington, DC: World Bank.

2 
processes, including “smart” infrastructure that incorporates sensors and remote sensing, often 
at high frequency. Administrative information is increasingly available, and the coverage and 
quality of microdata from national statistical systems are increasing in many DMCs. Computerized 
service delivery can also enable new forms of large-scale experiments to rapidly test innovations. 
 
6.  IE is essential to strengthen ADB’s role as a knowledge provider, as outlined in Strategy 
2030.7 Initially,  IEs  at  ADB  were  largely  carried  out  through  individual  efforts  of  regional 
departments. Recognizing the need for a more systematic approach to measure project outcomes 
and impacts, ERCD developed a research and development TA titled Implementing Impact 
Evaluation at ADB in 2010, which funded five pilot IEs.8 This work was supplemented in 2013 with 
TA cluster (CTA) 0012-REG: Developing Impact Evaluation Methodologies, Approaches, and 
Capacities in Selected Developing Member Countries to support (i) about 15 IE study phases 
distributed over ADB’s regional departments and ERCD, (ii) the development of IE methodologies, 
and (iii) awareness raising and capacity building on IE among the DMCs.9 Under both TA projects, 
IE was to have support from ERCD, but conduct remained largely an regional department 
responsibility. Providing evidence-based policy recommendations aligns with the value addition 
sought by ADB’s Strategy 2030. 
 
7.  CTA 0012 initiated 19 IE studies (21 study phases) covering 8 sectors in 11 DMCs. It led 
to 4 conferences, 10 seminars, an IE portal, IE reviews on energy and transport, and an IE 
guidebook. As a result, awareness and momentum have increased at ADB for conducting IE.  
 
8.  Although CTA 0012 initiated many studies, few have been completed to date, in part 
because IEs often require multiple surveys spanning prior and post-project implementation. The 
initiated IEs have not all had consistent technical oversight from regional departments, some of 
which lack staff with a background in IE. As a result, some initiated IEs have insufficient sample 
sizes, survey design limitations, or other problems that impede successful conclusion. 
 
9.  More effective mainstreaming of IE requires improved support. Continued support is 
needed to ensure that promising studies that have been initiated are completed, and appropriate 
new studies are initiated. In addition, support needs to be improved by consistently ensuring that 
financial resources are accompanied by appropriate technical expertise and oversight through 
more of a “One ADB” approach, in which research economists from ERCD can be fully engaged 
in studies along with global experts who may be associated with other networks or agencies 
(possible examples include the Jamal-Latif Poverty Action Lab, Innovations for Poverty Action or 
IDinsight).10 TA support to IE studies will be further improved to focus support more strategically 
to add value to operations. This includes (i) adopting nimble approaches for IEs to enable more 
rapid completion, (ii) targeting understudied themes, and (iii) supporting IE of pilot interventions 
under consideration for future investments. Thus, additional resources will be required to (i) 
support ongoing IE studies for completion, (ii) support new IE studies; (iii) disseminate study 
findings and lessons, and (iv) contribute to capacity building of DMC stakeholders. 
 
 
7  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
8  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Implementing Impact Evaluation at ADB. Manila (TA 7680-REG). 
9  A brief description of impact evaluation studies implemented under ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for Developing 
Impact Evaluation Methodologies, Approaches and Capacities in Selected Developing Member Countries. Manila 
(Cluster TA 0012-REG) is provided in Supplementary Appendix A. 
10 The organizations indicated are for illustrative purposes, and does not imply any specific consultancy work is 
intended.

3 
III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
10.  The envisaged effect of the TA is that IE is mainstreamed to a greater degree in ADB 
operations, resulting in better-designed investments in DMCs.11  Although innovative approaches 
can help in conducting cost-effective and timely IEs, many IEs may take more than 5 years to 
complete, because project implementation can take years, and additional years may be needed 
before effects of interest can be observed. Long-term commitment is needed to support studies 
through this process. An individual freestanding TA would either have long periods of committed 
resources with little disbursement (if all survey rounds are funded), or will create uncertainty about 
whether funds are available to complete IEs (if only individual survey rounds are funded). Use of 
a TA cluster modality to finance individual rounds of data collection allows flexibility for this 
situation. A cluster with a phased series of subprojects ensures that future funds will be available, 
while committing funds only to activities with near-term disbursements for the initial subprojects. 
By establishing a substantial central funding pool, the TA cluster enables strategic selection of 
IEs with the greatest potential, while reducing costs otherwise devoted for processing individual 
studies as stand-alone TA projects. 
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
11.  The  TA  cluster  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact  derived  from  Strategy  2030: 
development effectiveness of ADB finance and partnerships enhanced.7 The TA cluster will have 
the following outcome: consideration of evidence on the effectiveness of interventions in ADB 
operations and discussions informing DMC policies expanded.12 The TA cluster will have three 
subprojects and two outputs. 
 
12.  Output 1: Impact evaluation studies conducted. This will support the conduct of at least 
15 IE study phases, while maintaining regional and sector balance. IE studies will be applied to 
ADB  investments  or  pilot  interventions  for  informing  future  ADB  investments.  The  TA  will 
strategically support IE studies from beginning to end, ensure that previously initiated IEs are 
completed, and encourage low-cost and nimble approaches, especially on understudied themes. 
It may also support key phases of individual studies, with other phases financed independently.13 
The TA also will support collaboration with leading research partners on rigorous IE analysis and 
publish high-quality ADB reports and research papers. It may also allocate limited funding for 
diagnostic work to scope promising IE study possibilities and prepare proposals. 
 
13.  Output 2: Impact evaluation awareness and capacity enhanced. This output will entail 
(i) reviewing IE methodologies and results for sectors and themes, and producing synthesis 
knowledge products; (ii) conducting (a) IE awareness raising and capacity building for DMC 
officials involved and/or potentially involved in supported IEs; and (b) workshops and seminars 
where global research experts will be invited to share methods, practices, and lessons on IE; and 
(iii) improving and maintaining the current IE data portal to ensure that the products from output 
1 are preserved and put to maximum use. 
 
 
11 Impact evaluation is mainstreamed in ADB operations when it is integrated in the process of designing projects in 
DMCs based on experience from the actual conduct of (i) IEs that adopt appropriate methodologies, (ii) knowledge-
sharing workshops and conferences, and (iii) capacity building activities. 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
13 If only the study design or baseline survey can be implemented under the TA, commitment may be required from 
regional departments concerned to undertake mid-line and/or end-line surveys and/or studies.

4 
14.  External publications arising from the TA will be disseminated to targeted DMC officials 
and other relevant stakeholder in compliance with the administrative order on environment, 
health, and safety management.14 Because the nature of publications will be driven by the 
proposal selection decisions of the impact evaluation committee (IEC), specific target audiences 
and  resulting  demands  for  printed  publications  will  necessarily  be  determined  during  TA 
implementation. Prior to undertaking any printing, the TA will determine specific target readers, 
estimated  required  numbers  of  copies,  and  associated  printing  and  freight  costs,  while 
recognizing that printing of external publications is an exceptional arrangement, and that printing 
in excess of demand is to be avoided. Technical reports will be accompanied by other formats 
accessible to less technical audiences, such as policy briefs, as appropriate. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $4,500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
TASF-6 and TASF-Others.15 The three intended subprojects under the cluster will have an 
allocation of $1,500,000 each, with subproject 1 to be funded within 2019, followed by the other 
subprojects in subsequent years. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will administer the TA, with ERCD responsible for its overall implementation and 
supervision. Oversight and guidance will be by an IEC,16 which will be a modification of the IEC 
established under CTA 0012, comprising representatives (one principal and one alternate)17 from 
ADB’s regional departments; ERCD; Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department; 
Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial  Management  Department;  and  Strategy,  Policy  and 
Partnerships Department. It will be chaired by the ERCD chief economist and director general 
and cochaired by a member from another department. Other departments will be invited to 
contribute as observers. For output 1, the IEC will approve all funded studies, while ERCD and 
the  concerned regional  department  will  be  jointly responsible for conducting the  studies.18 
Regional departments will propose candidate areas of focus for IE and ensure project and country 
stakeholder support, DMC no-objection or approval, and coordination between the TA and project 
undergoing evaluation. Consultant oversight will be undertaken jointly by ERCD and regional 
departments, wherein regional departments will ensure operational relevance, and ERCD will be 
available, as needed, for ensuring the technical quality of data collection, analysis, and knowledge 
products as needed. ERCD will serve as secretariat for the IEC. 
 
17.  To identify well-designed IE studies and allow enough selectivity to maintain regional and 
sector balance, the IEC will call for proposals for IE phases to be funded, with a deadline.19 Each 
subproject will have a separate request for proposals, under a distinct thematic focus selected by 
the IEC. ERCD will offer technical support on developing proposals. Limited funds (up to $30,000) 
 
14 TA publications will be disseminated as electronic files by default and in compliance with ADB. 2008. Environment, 
Health and Safety Management System Administrative Order.AO 4.13 Manila. However, because printed external 
publications remain in demand for selected target readers from DMCs and ADB project staff and management, 
limited printed copies will be made available. 
15 Use of TASF-6 Funds will be in compliance with the country restrictions for those funds under regional TA. 
16 The structure of the IEC is described in Supplementary Appendix B. 
17 Alternate representatives will also be nominated in case the principal representatives are not available for a meeting. 
18 No-objection will be sought from respective governments of DMCs prior to commencing IE studies. 
19 Each proposal is typically expected not to exceed about $200,000 and the subproject duration. The proposal may 
cover one or multiple data collection rounds, such as baseline (pre-intervention), mid-line (after partial intervention), 
end-line (after full intervention), and/or post-end line (longer after full intervention) surveys and/or analysis. The total 
allocation from the TA cluster for all rounds of a given study should not exceed $500,000.

5 
for diagnostics and proposal preparation may be approved on a rolling basis by the IEC. Each 
submitted proposal will include both regional department and ERCD team members, and may 
also include staff from other departments. IEC members will select new proposals to be supported 
according to criteria reflecting cost-effectiveness,20 operational relevance, understudied sectors, 
technical rigor, feasibility,21 and contribution to knowledge gaps. Gender-differentiated analysis 
will be encouraged. ERCD will provide technical appraisals to inform IEC funding approval.22 Key 
intermediate IE elements, including inception reports; survey instruments and sampling designs; 
and data cleaning, preparation, and analysis scripts will be submitted to the TA secretariat and 
archived in a data repository system managed by ERCD. 
 
18.  Results of IE studies will be published as reports or as stand-alone working papers, 
accompanied by briefs or other products accessible to nontechnical audiences. ERCD will 
propose, and if approved by the IEC, implement activities that fall under output 2 of the TA in 
collaboration with regional departments, and other departments as appropriate. 
 
19.  Implementation of the TA cluster and subproject 1 will commence on 20 December 2019 
with subprojects 2 and 3 planned for initiation in 2020 and 2021. TA cluster completion is 
scheduled on 20 December 2026, for a total implementation period of just over 6 years. The 
implementation period exceeds 5 years to enable studies to be supported from beginning to end 
and allow sufficient time to measure longer-term effects when needed. The duration of each 
subproject is 5 years. Each TA subproject proposal will be submitted for approval to the ERCD 
head of department, in accordance with the business process for knowledge and support TA 
cluster processing. Subproject activities will start only after approval. 
 
 
 
 
20 Where possible, study proposals that are less costly while meeting the other criteria, will be prioritized.  In addition, 
the TA encourages proposals for mid-line or end-line surveys, especially where baseline surveys were funded by 
previous subprojects of the TA. 
21 Feasibility will refer to appraisal of risks to study success, as well as the expected study duration, with preference for 
rapid studies with fewer implementation risks, such as those using “big data” and other existing datasets. 
22 To avoid conflicts of interest appraisals will be conducted by ERCD staff or consultants that are not members of the 
team proposing the study. Those involved in preparing and/or implementing specific proposals will also abstain from 
voting on such proposals.

6

20.  Subprojects. The TA cluster will be implemented through three subprojects (Appendix 2). 
Each subproject will be designed to support the achievement of the cluster outputs (paras. 12–
13) as and when needed during the implementation period. Each subproject covers at least five 
IE study phases,23 for a total of 15 study phases distributed over ADB’s regional departments. 
 
Table 2: Indicative Implementation Period and Budget Allocation for Subprojects

21.  Consulting services. Each of the IE studies will require a team of consultants, both 
international and national, to be engaged separately. The consultants will (i) provide technical 
guidance and feedback on the initial IE concept, (ii) develop the design of the IE studies together 
with the ADB team, (iii) assist in guiding and overseeing the implementation of IE studies, (iv) 
assist in survey and sampling design, (v) implement the surveys, and (vi) assist in data analysis 
and report preparation. In addition, other consultants will need to backstop activities beyond the 
individual studies (including output 2, as well as overall support to output 1), by supporting 
outreach, helping to monitor and improve IE efforts by the study teams, ensuring that ADB 
knowledge products are generated from studies, preparing synthesis reports, and contributing to 
capacity building. 
 
 
23 A “phase” refers to a survey round, such as a baseline or end-line survey. Most IEs are based on two survey rounds.

7 
22.  Consequently, the TA cluster will require the services of a mix of individual consultants 
and firms. Support beyond individual IE studies by international IE experts and editors and 
national research associates, project coordinators, and layout artists will be through individual 
consulting services. The precise composition of firms and individual consultants for IE studies 
funded under output 1 will depend on the proposals approved by the IEC. Some studies may 
contract  specific  roles  through  individual  consultant  selection  or  framework  agreements, 
supplemented by nonconsulting services for data. Others may be contracted through firms via 
selection methods determined based on the resource needs of the IE studies. Purchase of goods, 
data, and information technology equipment within consulting contracts will be allowed if justified 
to be cost-effective and approved by ADB. Subject to approval of the ADB’s Procurement, 
Portfolio, and Financial Management Department, single-source selection will be used when the 
proposed engagement is a continuation of previously initiated work and/or there is only one firm 
with capacity to deliver the proposed IE tasks. The consultants will be engaged in accordance 
with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and the associated 
Project Administration Instructions and/or Staff Instructions.  
 
23.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time), the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time); and Staff Instructions for TA Procurement of Goods, Works and Nonconsulting 
Services. Nonconsulting services for separately contracted data collection will be procured using 
open  advertisement  or request  for  quotation. Procurement  of  equipment  will  take  place  in 
coordination  with  ADB’s  Office  of  Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  Office  of 
Administrative Services. When the TA is completed, any procured equipment will remain ADB 
property and/or will be disposed of in accordance with relevant ADB guidelines. Disbursements 
under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s  Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
V.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $4,500,000 on a grant basis for 
Mainstreaming  Impact  Evaluation  Methodologies,  Approaches,  and  Capacities  in  Selected 
Developing Member Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
A. Subproject 1 (target approval date: December 2019) 
1.  IE studies conducted 
1.1 Screen and select projects for IE studies (December 2019–December 2020).

Inputs 
ADB: $4,500,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6 and TASF-Others)

Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, DMC = developing member country, IE = impact evaluation, IEC = impact evaluation 
committee, TA = technical assistance, TASF =Technical Assistance Special Fund. 
a  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
b  Impact evaluation has three main outcome pathways: 1) direct pathway of study findings informing the design of 
similar subsequent projects; 2) process pathway of interaction between the impact evaluation and project teams 
leading to improvements prior to any findings; and 3) broader conceptual pathway in which findings inform other 
research and discussions to influence policies in a range of contexts and countries. The third pathway is often the 
most important over the long term, but is also difficult to track or predict in the short term, so it has no direct target. 
c  Based on (i) five key sets of reporting per funded study (inception report, sampling plan, questionnaire, raw data, 
and data analysis with preparation scripts); (ii) study reports/papers; (iii) twice-yearly updates on each study; (iv) 
quarterly financial updates; (v) workshops; and (vi) synthesis reports. Updates are considered timely if they occur 
when details are available, or at the regular reporting frequency. 
d  Fund source of $1,250,000 is from TASF-6 and $250,000 from TASF-Others.  Additional TASF-Others financing may 
be sought in 2020 to enable continuation of activities in countries ineligible for TASF-6 support under regional TA.  
Source: Asian Development Bank.

Appendix 2  11 
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Mainstreaming Impact Evaluation Methodologies, Approaches, and 
Capacities in Selected Developing Member Countries 
Indicative outputs and  Output 1 will conduct at least five impact evaluation (IE) study phases 
activities  (which each may contain surveys, analyses, or both). The TA will 
strategically support IEs, ensure that previously initiated IEs are 
successfully completed, and encourage low-cost approaches, especially on 
understudied themes. New studies will be supported under a theme to be 
defined by the impact evaluation committee (IEC). The TA may also 
support key phases of individual studies, with other phases financed 
independently. The TA will also support collaboration with leading research 
partners on rigorous IE analysis and publish high-quality ADB reports and 
research papers. It may also allocate small funding amounts for diagnostic 
work to scope promising IE possibilities and prepare proposals.  
Key activities will include: 
(i)  screening and selection of IE proposals, 
(ii)  engagement of consultants, 
(iii) preparation of inception reports, 
(iv) conduct of IEs, and 
(v)  publication of IEs and dissemination of reports. 
 
Output 2 will enhance IE awareness and capacity among ADB DMCs. This 
entails (i) reviewing IE methodologies and results for sectors and themes, 
and producing synthesis knowledge products; (ii) conducting IE awareness 
raising and capacity building for DMC officials involved in supported IEs, 
and workshops and seminars, where global research experts will be invited 
to share methods, practices, and lessons on IE; and (iii) improving and 
maintaining the current IE data portal to ensure that the products of output 
1 are preserved and put to maximum use. 
Key activities will include: 
(i)  conducting technical workshops in ADB DMCs, 
(ii)  organizing regional conference(s) and seminars on IE, and 
(iii) developing synthesis reports. 
 
Indicative  ADB will administer the TA, with ERCD responsible for its overall 
implementation  implementation and supervision. Overall guidance and oversight will be 
arrangements  provided by an IEC, comprising representatives (one principal and one 
alternate)a from ADB’s regional department; ERCD; Sustainable 
Development and Climate Change Department; and Strategy, Policy, and 
Partnerships Department, and chaired by the chief economist. Other 
departments will contribute as observers. 
 
The IEC will approve all funded studies, with ERCD and regional 
departments jointly responsible for conducting the studies. The regional 
departments will (i) propose candidate areas of focus for IEs; and (ii) 
ensure project and country stakeholder support, DMC no-objection or 
approvals, and coordination between the TA and project undergoing 
evaluation. Consultant oversight will be undertaken jointly by ERCD and 
regional departments, with regional departments ensuring operational 
relevance, and ERCD ensuring the technical quality of data collection, 
analysis, and knowledge products as needed. ERCD will serve as 
secretariat for the IEC.

Subproject 2  Mainstreaming Impact Evaluation Methodologies, Approaches, and 
Capacities in Selected Developing Member Countries 
Indicative outputs and  Subproject 2 will basically follow the two main outputs of subproject 1. For 
activities  output 1, another set of five IE phases (surveys) applying various 
methodologies and survey instruments will be conducted. Previously 
initiated IEs will be supported to ensure the successful completion of 
studies. However, new studies with nimble and low-cost approaches, and 
key phases of individual studies (with other phases financed independently) 
will also be encouraged under a common theme identified by the IEC. 
Output 2 will continue to enhance IE awareness and capacity among the 
DMCs by (i) producing knowledge products to synthesize results on specific 
sectors or themes, (ii) conducting IE awareness capacity-building 
workshops, and (iii) improving and maintaining the IE portal.
